For homeless families,
hotel is a life in limbo

With shelters overflowing, the state uses hotels to meet the needs of a surge of Mass. families who have become homeless in the past few years.

War of words erupts over library plan

A push to build a new, 5,800-square-foot library, a source of tension among Shutesbury’s 1,700 residents, has fed bitter, acrimonious debate in recent months.

Felons’ DNA test database has gaps

Massachusetts officials have failed to collect DNA samples of 20,000 convicted felons, leaving a hole in the State Police database.

In Boston, ‘tonic’ gives way to ‘soda’

For most Bostonians, the carbonated drink is now ‘‘soda,’’ not ‘‘tonic,’’ and the final volume of a new dictionary sheds light on the history of the usage.
Opinion | Joanna Weiss

A calculated risk for at-risk kids

What if the system works, the rules are followed, the risks are correctly assessed, and something still goes terribly, tragically wrong?

Facing trial, but still in real estate

More than a year after Michael David Scott was charged with running a mortgage scam, the developer works as a licensed broker selling distressed properties.

Reunion, tribute at Harvard auction

The art and furniture collection of the late Rev. Peter J. Gomes was auctioned, in an event that was part Harvard reunion, part bittersweet memorial service.
